column10: Ltd. and a subsidiary of Bandai Namco Holdings
column11: Inc.Most of the anime and films that have been distributed and licensed by Bandai Visual have been released under the Emotion label. After the reorganization of Bandai Namco Holdings in 2006
column12: Bandai Visual headed the group's Visual and Music Content Strategic Business Unit. Its subsidiaries included the Emotion Music Company
column13: Ltd. (whose logos also include the Moai from Easter Island)
column14: and Lantis music publishing labels. Until 2012
column15: it was involved in the production and distribution of several anime titles
column16: including those it has directly produced itself and anime series produced by the anime studio Sunrise
column17: an alternate anime studio subsidiary of Bandai Namco Holdings. In September 2017
column18: Bandai Visual acquired the anime studio Actas.In February 2018
column19: it was announced Bandai Visual would be merged with Lantis into a new branch of BNH
column20: called Bandai Namco Arts. The reorganizing took effect as of April 1
column21: 2018. Bandai Visual remains only as a label of the new company.

column1: Bandai Visual is currently a fully owned subsidiary of Bandai Namco Holdings. Bandai Namco announced on November 8
column2: 2007 that it would buy the voting shares it did not own between that date and December 10
column3: 2007 and turn the company into a wholly owned subsidiary. On December 18
column5: Bandai Namco announced that it had owned 93.63% of Bandai Visual's shares since the end of November. The remaining shares were delisted from the Tokyo Stock Exchange on February 15
column6: 2008 after Bandai Namco acquired the remaining 10% of the shares.

column1: Bandai Entertainment was a subsidiary of Bandai America
column2: founded in 1998. Their first releases were under the AnimeVillage.com label up until 1999 when Bandai Entertainment started releasing its titles. Despite its name it was not directly established by Bandai Visual. Originally separate from Bandai Visual USA
column3: Bandai Namco Holdings announced that Bandai Entertainment would absorb Bandai Visual USA in 2008. Headquartered in Cypress
column5: it licensed anime properties from various Japanese companies for North American distribution; most of those licenses coming from Bandai and its sister company Sunrise. The company also licensed manga series for release with English translation
column6: and published American-made graphic novels. As with many North American anime distributors
column7: Bandai Entertainment offered a 'fan support' program to facilitate public screenings of licensed content at anime clubs and anime conventions. The company confirmed on January 2
column8: 2012 that they would stop offering new DVD
column9: Blu-ray disc and manga releases by February
column10: but would continue to produce their current library of content. Bandai Entertainment was restructured to focus on licensing anime to other companies. On August 30
column12: Bandai America announced that it will shut down Bandai Entertainment and discontinue distributing their home video and print catalog on March 1
column13: 2013. They made their final shipment to retailers on November 30
column14: 2012. Many former Bandai Entertainment titles have been re-licensed by other companies like Funimation

column1: Beez Entertainment was the European branch of Bandai Entertainment that also distributed anime and music and were also owned by Bandai Namco Holdings. The name is an acronym for Bandai Entertainment European Zone. Following the discontinuation of Bandai Entertainment
column2: Beez has also stopped releasing anime in the European market. Their anime releases were licensed in North America by Bandai Entertainment and Bandai Visual USA.

column1: Bandai Visual USA was established in 2005 to distribute and market Bandai Visual's productions in North America. Unlike Bandai Entertainment
column2: Bandai Visual USA's releases were of high quality and were aimed at collectors. Their titles were released under the Honnêamise label (named after their Bandai Visual's first production
column3: Royal Space Force: The Wings of Honnêamise).  Bandai Visual USA's anime products were distributed in North America initially by Image Entertainment and later
column4: Geneon Entertainment USA and in Europe by Beez Entertainment.  On May 23
column6: Bandai Namco Holdings announced that Bandai Visual USA would be merged into Bandai Entertainment. Bandai Visual USA was dissolved on July 1

column1: Honnêamise was Bandai Visual USA's boutique label that distributed deluxe editions of anime and artsier products. The label's namesake comes from Royal Space Force: The Wings of Honnêamise. The label was shut down on July 1
column2: 2008 when Bandai Visual USA was absorbed into Bandai Entertainment. The label's releases were distributed by Geneon Entertainment USA and Image Entertainment.

column2: Bandai Visual had their first music release on US iTunes with Lantis Sounds.  In September 2009
column3: Bandai Visual teamed up with NAMCO for their periodic release of game sounds (classic and new) to iTunes USA.
